DOC.HEAD: Zoo Director Pulls Panamanian Toads
Eds: Note language in last graf
DOC.TEXT: An exhibit of Panamanian toads at the Columbus Zoo has been pulled in the wake of the U.S. attempt to oust Gen. Manuel Noriega from power, the zoo's director says. A group of zoo animals were scheduled for an appearance Wednesday on ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' as part of a Christmas show, said Jack Hanna, zoo director. But the fighting in Panama pre-empted coverage of the exhibit. Hanna, in response to the fighting, then ordered that the toads be taken off exhibit. Hanna said zoo staff members had been preparing for the television appearance since 4:30 a.m. Wednesday. ``ABC had brought in a satellite truck from Virginia, two producers and a director from New York. Two cameras were ready to roll,'' Hanna said. ``(Head curator) Don Winstel was standing out there with a camel and her baby, two sheep, two goats, reindeer and a miniature donkey,'' Hanna said. But the network said there would not ``be any Christmas animals today because we're at war with Panama,'' Hanna said. ``I never did like that SOB Noriega; now I hate him.''
